title: Tori Spelling says 'screw the shamers' after being criticized for daughters' dyed hair
text:
CLOSE

Tori Spelling got mom-shamed for letting her kids dye their hair for a costume party. (Photo: Rich Polk, Getty Images for Nights of the J)

Tori Spelling is not here for being mom shamed.

The "Beverly Hills, 90210" alum said "screw the shamers" after some critics left negative comments on an Instagram post about her daughters' dyed hair and makeup.

The mom of five attended a L.O.L. Surprise! Winter Disco launch party with three of her kids and husband Dean McDermott and shared photos to her social media page. Her daughters, Stella, 11, and Hattie, 7, were pictured wearing reddish hair dye and pink makeup on their eyelids.

While it appeared that most comments were positive,, one said that the girls were too young to be wearing makeup and dyeing their hair.

"What is with all the makeup and dying those girls hair? Too young for that Tori!!!!" the commenter wrote.

In an interview with US Weekly, Spelling said her family was at a costume party where everyone was encouraged to come dressed as their favorite L.O.L. doll.

"First of all, it was Halloween costumes in pink, and it washes out the next day,” the mom told Us Weekly. “It wasn’t dye at all. The party, was like, come dressed as your favorite L.O.L. It was a costume dress party where girls can be anything they want to be and screw the shamers."

Spelling isn't the first celebrity mom to get dissed for dyeing her daughter's hair — whether permanently or temporarily.

Jessica Simpson recently faced backlash for letting her 7-year-old daughter Maxwell Drew add purple highlights to her long blonde locks. The look was inspired by Disney Channel's "Descendants" film franchise.

"So sad to see a child this young getting her hair dyed. She looked so much prettier with her natural golden locks. She still should be a child in every sense," one commented.

Simpson did not respond to the critics, but singer Pink did.

The fellow mom, who's faced her own battles with the parenting police, took to Instagram to defend Simpson by sharing a photo of herself dyeing her 8-year-old daughter Willow's hair blue.

She added several hashtags like "blue hair don't care," "get your own kids" and "parent police are actually just lonely sad people."

Contributing Cydney Henderson
